fun_fact: Home to one of the tallest twin towers in the world, Kuala Lumpur is the capital of Malaysia.
Located off the coast of Sabah, Labuan has mesmerizing dive sites and duty-free shopping.
Home to the famous pink Putra Mosque, Putrajaya is the federal administrative centre of Malaysia.
Johor is the only state with their own army force, the Royal Johor Military Force.
Known as the Rice Bowl of Malaysia, Kedah produces more than half of the country's rice supply.
The unique Kelantanese Malay language is incomprehensible even for habitual Malay speakers.
With 3 eras of colonial influence, Melaka is the birthplace of the nation's historical and cultural heritage.
Made up of nine counties, Negeri Sembilan is the only state that practises the matrilineal social system.
The diverse landscapes of Pahang ranges from highlands to rainforests to beaches.
The name Penang is derived from the betel nut tree, which is 'Pinang' in Malay.
A name derived from the once abundant silvery tin-ore deposits, Perak means 'silver' in Bahasa Melayu.
Perlis is home to the Sanai Limestone, a rare Devonian limestone unit.
Sabah is home to Malaysia's tallest mountain, Mount Kinabalu, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
As the largest state of Malaysia, Sarawak is rich in natural resources such as timber and oil.
As the most happening state, Selangor is 'home' to many Malaysians from other states.
As the 'Gem of East Coast' with a coastline of 244km, Terengganu is home to pristine tropical islands.
